Message.Msg: All IMHO. Please do your thorough DD of course. Selling first thing in the morning (pre-market if possible). Its like after Q1 results ... 9:30am was the high of the day. I've gone through the results with a fine tooth comb. The internal picture isn't pretty as such... actually the fwd. guidance was below the expected mid-point. Matching the loss of 9 cents won't cut it at this high multiple. I suspect it will drift down now for many months to come. No matter what you do: Do not sell puts for 300, 275, 250 strikes, thinking its far out. Most likely those will get assigned to you. If you are holding calls, close them as soon as possible (with "that's all she wrote" theme). Do not compare AMZN with GOOG ... GOOG is in a totally different class by itself. AMZN is too expensive as a hot-potato to hold now ... chances of a burn are high. You'll see big boys dumping heavily and then moving on to other plays, as they know that these are the best prices they'll ever get from this. And they help move the pps ... not small, retail Joes and Jills. Chances are slim, but, I'll not be surprised if a God-fearing analyst, who has some slight conscience still left in him, might land-up downgrading this at this level. All the best, whatever you do.

Topic.Title: Increase in revenue probably attributable to

Message.Msg: The accounting change was a result a settlement between Apple and book publishers. Publishers ended their agency agreements which negated the commissions they were paying to retailers selling their books. How did this effect Amazon? When accounting for a book sale through an agency agreement, they only "booked" the commission. With the agency agreements gone, Amazon now books those revs as a merchant. Amazon now books the sale as 100% revenue as opposed to the commission, which was a fraction of the book sale. TA-DAH.....those book sales are accounted for up to 3X their previous entry.....neat huh? Of course, there's no change in operating profit. Did I say profit?......does that matter with Amazon?

Message.Title: REvenue beat fake
Message.Msg: At least Anmuth from JPM asked "how much the shift from 3P to 1P for EBooks boosted revenue" and as usual the CFO's answer was "can't help you there" Douglas Anmuth - JPMorgan Great, thanks for taking the question. Just want to ask two things. First, Tom, can you give us some color on where you are in the shift from third-party to first-party e-books and how much of the factor that’s been in reaccelerating media revenue, you have seen reacceleration in media in the last three quarters, I think in North America? And then secondly, it looks like there is six fewer shopping days this holiday season between Black Friday and Christmas, just curious what you do with anything differently to prepare for that and do you think that could actually even drive more holiday shopping online? Thanks. Tom Szkutak Sure. In terms of your second one, second question, there are fewer days. There is not a lot that we do different. We certainly see when that happens. And there is some behavioral differences on behalf of customers just because of the shorter time period that we have certainly some more sizable days during that period, but there is not a lot to add to that. In terms of the transition for e-books, in terms of our total growth across Amazon both North America total, our global total, it’s not a significant or meaningful impact to the overall growth rates and certainly this transition has been going on for you know some number of quarters now so it's not a lot I can help you with there.

Message.Msg: Keep trying Nem. Fulfillment cost as a % of net sales have been systematically increasing, just as inventory turns have been decreasing. The fact that the trading scam has gone parabolic doesn't change the underlying economics... I've been correct about the underlying economics. By the way, guiding to a possible loss in the most profitable quarter for a retailer is a TRAIN WRECK...

Topic.Title: Think about this ....

Message.Msg: n59218, thanks for the note. Try as they might, all those who incessantly attack me here (Geeg, Nem, Nas) do not affect me. While few on this board seem to understand measuring one's impact in other than financial terms, I do. The measuring stick everyone here is using will break soon enough and those (like Nas, Nem and Geeg) will find themselves ill-equipped to function in a world where finance normalizes. The main reason I started focusing on all these scams was that HFT was beating down companies engaged in science based innovation while blowing massive bubbles in consumer oriented #$%$ (burritos, yoga, Scamazon, etc.). The misallocation of capital from these float jam scams (where concentrated institutional longs engage in tacit collusion, becoming traders/sellers of option premium, while HFT/quant/algo scalp premium and squeeze retail) has undermined real innovation. Globalization has essentially run its course and only science based innovation is going to get us through the resource and demographic crunch that is coming. As such, I don't regret what has happened. It has crystallized for me what is coming and where value will be in the future. I'm positioned for the future, not for today. Besides, I had a great day today -- I just got a notice of allowance for a pretty fundamental patent on MEMS devices.
